node.title: Vaccine Requirement for Kids to Enter NYC Restaurants Among Strict New COVID Restrictions
node.alt: New York City will require proof of vaccination for children ages 5 to 11 to enter restaurants, gyms, theaters and other places. Above, a sign asking patrons to wear a face mask at the entrance of a restaurant in midtown Manhattan on August 3.
node.description: New York's mayor also announced a "first-in-the-nation" vaccine mandate for all private sector workers.
node.content:
["New York City will require proof of coronavirus vaccination for children ages 5 to 11 to enter restaurants, gyms, theaters and other places.", "Mayor Bill de Blasio announced the mandate on Monday morning, citing the new Omicron variant and ongoing Delta surge as reasons to take a new step to reduce the spread of the coronavirus. The mayor also announced a \"first-in-the-nation\" vaccine mandate for all private sector workers that goes into effect December 27.", "\"We've got Omicron as a new factor,\" de Blasio said on MSNBC. \"We've got the colder weather, which is going to really create new challenges with the Delta variant. We've got holiday gatherings. We in New York City have decided to use a preemptive strike to really do something bold to stop the further growth of COVID and the dangers it poses to all of us.\"", "Kids between 5 and 11 will have to receive their first shot to be able to eat in restaurants, use indoor fitness areas and for indoor entertainment spaces such as movie theaters, museums, arcades and other places. Just 20 percent of kids in this age group are already vaccinated, according to De Blasio's press secretary, Danielle Filson.", "Adults have been required to show vaccination proof to enter such areas since the so-called \"Key to NYC\" program began in August.", "This is a developing story and will be updated with more information as it becomes available.", "", "
New York City will require proof of vaccination for children ages 5 to 11 to enter restaurants, gyms, theaters and other places. Above, a sign asking patrons to wear a face mask at the entrance of a restaurant in midtown Manhattan on August 3.
"]
